title: If the Dao has no name, then how can it be called the Dao? - Quora

response.answer_text: Dao and De are the subject matter of the famous Dao De Jing, whose author is known by the name of Laozi. The Dao part starts like this: 道可道非常道; The very first sign is the character for dao. Remark how it pops up again 2 more times further down. A quite literal translation would thus be: ‘the dao that can (可) be dao-ed is not (非) the permanent (常) dao’ whereby the 2d ‘dao’ denotes a verb usually translated as to say, to utter . We now have: the dao (Dao?) that can be expressed is not the permanent dao. (another version: the Dao that can be trodden is not the during, permanent Dao - ‘dao’ = ‘way’) So the text itself starts by stating the paradox. It then continues in parallel: The name that can be named is not the real name. And goes on: As nameless, it is the beginning of heaven and earth /Named, it is the Mother of the 10,000 things. Notice how the paradox is continued - any further elaboration of meaning and purport is now a question of interpretation. As to the paradox of giving a name to something that fundamentally has no name or cannot have one: if there’s no name at all for it, it cannot even be named. The paradox needs to be stated in order to live it. The expression of the unexpressable needs to be expressed… The received text dates from around the 6d century BC. No doubt there’s a religious / mystical component to it. Greetings!

If the Dao has no name, then how can it be called the Dao? It seems that this question is closely related to the translation/interpretation of chapter twenty-five of the Tao Te Ching. The original sentence of chapter twenty-five related to the question is “ 吾不知其名，字之曰道，強為名之曰大。” And according to the author of the book “Tao Te Ching: The New English Version That Makes Good Sense”, this sentence can be translated and explained as: I do not know its name, just call it the Tao. And reluctantly I name it as the Great. “’the Great’ in this context means not only greatness, but also the ultimate ancestor of everyone (‘the mother of all things’). Lao Tzu ‘reluctantly’ named it as the Great because he understood quite well that he should not give a name to the Tao, the ultimate ancestor of everyone. In ancient times and even today, it is normal for parent to give names to their children, but not vice versa. Obviously, giving the ancestor a name is not considered as a respectful act to the ancestor, although it is technically doable. With such consideration, nobody, regardless how old he or she is, should give the Tao a name. And the Tao has never given itself a name. Thus, Lao Tzu said that I do not know its name. But he could not teach the Tao without mention of its name. Thus, he said that anyway, he just call it the Tao and reluctantly named it as the Great. Though, giving the Tao a name is disrespectful to it, but naming it the Great (which can mean the ultimate ancestor) itself proves that his true intention is to express respect and praise to it, which makes the naming action become acceptable or excusable.” In other words, since no one is older than the Dao, the Dao had not name before the ancient sage started calling it the Dao (or the Tao). Therefore, although “ the Dao (or the Tao)” can be considered as a name, but it is not a “formal name” that is usually given and called by parent to their child or by people to a thing. This is not because it’s technically undoable, but because we should not do that or we are disrespectful to it (by treating it as our child or a thing). In ancient China, the character “名” and “字” had different meanings in terms of naming and calling someone’s name. “名” as a verb means naming and calling children by their parent (we can consider such a name as a “birth name”. And since the Dao was never born, thus it has no such a name); while “字” as verb means giving a “public name” to someone after becoming an adult so that others (regardless of their ages) can use such a name to call her or him. Therefore, “the Dao (or the Tao)” can be considered as a name that it is known and called by everyone (the public). That is why Lao Tzu said that I do not know its name, just call it the Tao, And reluctantly I name it as the Great. This could be the true reason that although the Dao has no name (as its “birth name”), we still can call it the Dao (as its “public name”). Or we can say that the Dao has no name (as its “birth name”); the Dao has a name “the Dao” (as its “public name”). Thus, question is answered and there is no any paradox here. But on second thought, this question may also be somehow related to the translation/interpretation of chapter one of the Tao Te Ching. The original sentence of chapter one related to this question is “ 道可道，非常道；名可名，非常名。” For the explanation regarding to this sentence, please see my answer to the following question: Tiger's answer to What is the meaning of "The way that can be named is not the way" in Tao philosophy?

If the Dao has no name, then how can it be called the Dao? Tao is a placeholder name until some truly enlightening name comes along to take its place. Lucky for you you're in the right place and time to hear it. We know now from quantum mechanics that existence is calculable. It's called the probability function. Moreover, Born showed that the probability function is not a function of a hidden variable but rather that existence is made of probability. This affords us the opportunity to name that which is responsible for probability/existence as Possibility. If we compare Possibility to Tao all the pieces fit. Tao Moves. Possibility has unlimited freedom. Tao is comprised of opposites yin/yang and Possibility is both nothing (yin) and something (yang). While it used to be hard to convince yourself that "I am Tao" and thereby gain enlightenment, it's extremely easy to accept that "I am Possibility" and be enlightened, not just spiritually but scientifically. How cool is that?

Language is by its very nature limiting and confining of thought. If you wonder about this, learn a few different languages, and you will quickly discover that certain ideas or concepts are more easily expressed in one, may have to be slightly altered to work in another one, and may not easily be expressed at all in another. When one starts to talk about the ineffable, the infinite, and ultimate reality, this intrinsic quality of language becomes truly limiting. One of the key concepts of Taoism — and the parables of Christ, even — is that ultimate Truth is something that can be described as the blind men describing an elephant, with each man not being wrong, but only expressing truth in part, so that ultimate Truth is better yet pointed to. To take another example, St. Thomas Aquinas spent decades writing his Summa Theologica, but in the end also came to understand this particular truth. Hence, when the writer of the Tao Te Ching (道德經) was attempting to describe the Dao, the only recourse was to say in essence that if the reader thinks that by calling the true Dao the “Dao” they have then comprehended it, the reader is entirely mistaken. Language can only at best circumscribe in general terms, but not encompass completely. And anyone who believes the latter is quite mistaken and has NOT apprehended the true nature of the Dao.

* * * * * My first introduction to eastern philosophy came in 1986 with a book by Diane Dreher, The Tao of Inner Peace. Being a trained mathematician and physicist, this book presented me with something of a challenge. On first reading, I could not make much sense of her use of this word Tao — but I liked the overall feel of the book & I began to do short “centering exercises” at the start of each day. About three months later I returned to this book with a flash of insight. I took a pencil and drew a horizontal line through the word “Tao” everywhere it appeared in chapter one — and wrote instead the word “Wisdom”. * * * * * It worked for me. I continued this exercise right through to the end of the book. Everywhere I overwrote Tao with Wisdom. Then I closed the book and did the same to the title, which now became: The Wisdom of Inner Peace. In some weird way, I felt that I had made this book my own. This, then, became my “entry” into eastern philosophy. * * * * * Generally, words and names cannot be important. If you think that they are — well, you are being *distracted* by scribbles on paper. Yet each of us, somehow, must find his/her way — and this worked for me. * * * * *

As is without, so it is within. You do not need to know you to be you. So it is with the Dao. It is before you know, yet remains as known. You can open your eyes and see it, or close them so you can’t. As in existence we are here yet always there. The same and not the same is and is not. This is why the Dao has no name, and can still be called the Dao.
Because the finger that points at the moon is not the moon itself. The Dao truly has no name, but humans find labels temporarily useful in their learning process.

The Tao Te Ching says the Tao has no name, and what a name here means is an attribute, of course it has names, you could call it Tao, God, nature, or the universe, but that is an artificial name, it is not an attribute of the Tao itself, because the Tao has no qualities or attributes.
The blue sky has no blue in it, go and look in an aeroplane. Do you find the blue sky? And yet it has a name.

Because people think in terms of materiality and mind images, so are precluded to finite subjective concepts, which have severe limitations. So if we are trying to emphasize that which is infinte, we must reiterate that the finite aspects of that explanation as incomplete or ill equipped to explain the immensity of that infinity. L&L
